text: We just broke 400 users! we’re at 409! (beta and stable combined)
what are you stealing from me???
<https://github.com/williamspiro/HubSpot-Developer-Extension/wiki/Privacy-Policy>
quick response
suspicious

The permission to read and change data is required for the dark theme and the dev menu to function because we have to READ the html of the page to be able to inject the required code to make it work, and the change is the injection side itself
i got my eyes on  you, mclaren
:eyes:

The code is open source, and the only analytics/data leaving the extension itself is via a limited Google analytics integration and the Google Page Speed button(have to send your current url to google page speed to get analyzed)

Google analytics details are on the privacy policy page
:slightly_smiling_face:
idk, sounds kinda sketchy... :wink:
<@U7SL518D6> on the loose
mmhmm
he probably made that accept button blue so i would be more inclined to click it

lol, not that it matters, but I actually don’t control anything that appears in that permissions popup.

I can only control which sites it requests a permission for.

Should have seen the permission we had to use when we first built the extension
<https://media.giphy.com/media/l0IypMNwQqVbsXQ9W/giphy.gif>
Was it like some faustian scroll that you had to sign with your own blood?
no blood, just promises of first born child

It sounded really terrifying compared to what we actually used it for. it said something like “this extension will have access to your entire browsing history and can see and change anything on any of your tabs.[ I’m cool with that]”
the truth of the matter was all the permission granted us was the ability to check if a tab was a HubSpot tab, then if it was, inject our theme stylesheet .

But Google makes it scary because if an extension developer were clever and evil, they could have set it up using that permission, to ping their server every time you loaded a tab. essentially creating the “history”.

Google bans that, and we really don’t care to know what anyone’s looking at anyways

just as an FYI, the read and change on those 2 domains, basically means the extension is completely powerless off of HubSpot. we also when we need to access your current URL we can only do 1 instant action with it, then we litterally lose the variable. Google has some crazy security setup, the variable itself just ceases to exist and then the whole extension dies.
(this is one of the main reasons when you click the debug button or another of those buttons, the popup does not stay up, it litterally cannot, Google nukes it basically as a security precaution.

after working on the extension I gained a lot of respect for how thorough Google is with their security in this browser. They make all of the permissions sound terrifying so developers use the most restrictive ones intentionally to avoid scaring people, resulting in safer more secure extensions.
